The course of English political, legal and cultural history was changed in 1066, when William, Duke of Normandy (also called William the Conqueror) successfully invaded the nation and displaced the Saxon king, Harold II.

In 1066 King Edward, also called St Edward the Confessor, died. His cousin, the Duke of Normandy, claimed that the childless King had named him heir during a visit to France, and that the other claimant to the throne, Harold Godwinson, had pledged to support William when he was shipwrecked in Normandy. The veracity of this tale, however, is doubtful, and Harold took the crown upon King Edward's death. William, however, invaded England in September, and defeated (and killed) Harold at the famous Battle of Hastings in October.

chosen: William, who was also known as William the Conqueror, became the King of England in 1066 after defeating King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings. Some people believe that William was the rightful heir to the throne because King Edward had named him as his successor before he died. However, others dispute this claim and say that Harold should have been the next king since he was already ruling when Edward passed away.
rejected: In 1066, after the death of King Edward, also known as St Edward the Confessor, two men claimed the right to rule: Harold Godwinson, who was elected by the Witan, or council of nobles, and William, Duke of Normandy, who based his claim on an alleged promise made by King Edward during a visit to France. However, Harold was shipwrecked in Normandy and taken prisoner before he could be crowned. William then invaded England with a large army and defeated Harold at the Battle of Hastings. This battle marked the beginning of a new era in English history, as William brought with him a new language, culture, and legal system. This would eventually lead to the development of modern-day England.
